title: Intentionally Random
text:
How to Complete Quiz




If your computer is on, put it to sleep by clicking the apple in the top left, then “Sleep”
Write your first and last name
Write today’s date, Sept. 18
Use black/blue pen or pencil
Only use the left column
Fill in the correct bubble completely
You have twenty minutes.

title: Intentionally Random
text:
Play with randomness!
Go to In-Class Assignments>Random Shapes, and respond to BOTH forum prompts with screenshots:

Part 1: Try to create a random composition
Part 2: Let the computer create a random composition

title: Intentionally Random
text:
Questions to Consider

How does randomness reflect our world?
How can randomness enhance a design?
How can you control randomness for design that is both intentional and suprising?

title: Intentionally Random
section: How does human intention guide each of these examples?
text: How does human intention guide each of these examples?

title: Intentionally Random
text:
Math + Language Brainstorm
In your first project, you will:

use coding concepts from Week 1-4
use both math and language visually/conceptually. This prompt is open, as long as you can explain how you are using both.

The professor will set a timer. In your notebook, write and draw about a potential math + language project. Keep your pen moving the whole time. (You may also use a tablet)

title: Intentionally Random
text:
Exit Ticket
Turn in an image of your brainstorm in URCourses: In-Class Assignments > Math + Language Brainstorm

title: Conditionals
text:
Project Discussions
Get in a group with your table. Take turns reading your Math + Language project proposal out loud to each other. Give brief, respectful feedback on:

How the project incoporates math
How the project incorporates language
What p5.js features you might use to achieve your goal

title: Conditionals
text:
What are Conditionals?
Conditional statements allow your program to make decisions based on certain conditions. They use boolean expressions that evaluate to either true or false.
Think of it like: “IF this condition is true, THEN do this action.”

title: Conditionals
text:
Boolean Expressions
Boolean expressions compare values and return either true or false:
let x = 50;

x > 25     // true
x < 10     // false
x == 50    // true (equal to)
x != 30    // true (not equal to)

title: Conditionals
Conditionals
Conditionals
text:
Comparison Operators

> greater than
< less than

>= greater than or equal to
<= less than or equal to
== equal to
!= not equal to

title: Conditionals
Conditionals
Conditionals
Conditionals
text:
Logical Operators



Symbol
Name
Description




&&
AND
Both conditions must be true


||
OR
At least one condition must be true


!
NOT
Reverses the boolean value

title: Conditionals

or take notes if you prefer
